items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall. Today, Thursday 03/11/2022, is forecast to be largely dry, and the lake level at the Lodore gauge has levelled off. However the lake will remain high for at least the next few days, with further rain forecast over the coming weekend. Flooding is affecting locations near these rivers and the lake, with low lying land most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 04/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

No further flood impacts are expected in this area, and the flood alert has been removed for the North Sea Coast at Bridlington this morning, Thursday 03/11/22. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Upper Wey at Godalming as a result of persistent heavy rainfall last night. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads, footpaths and farmland is still expected. 
Light showers are expected over the coming days, but we expect levels on the river to drop overnight and remain below flood alert.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning, 04/11/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the River Pinn and Woodridings Stream as a result of persistent heavy rainfall on Wednesday 2nd and Thursday 3rd November 2022. The risk of flooding to roads and low-lying land is now reducing but river levels remain high. 

Further light rainfall is forecast this evening, Thursday 3rd November 2022 but we do not expect river levels to rise again as a result. We expect river levels to remain high overnight until tomorrow morning, Friday 4th November. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Friday 4th November, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected this evening 03/11/22, especially in the Free Prae Road area. 
Tonight, and tomorrow are relatively dry with some isolated showers. We expect river to fall overnight and into the morning.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 04/11/22, or if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there remains a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further rainfall is forecast overnight so we expect river levels to remain high. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded; refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Friday, 4/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed. As a result, there is currently not a risk of flooding in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message:
River levels are falling this morning on 03/03/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

At Buxted and Uckfield the river has fallen significantly from its peak Thursday. In Isfield, the river is still high but falling. Flood Warnings remain in force in Buxted and Isfield while there is uncertainty around the overnight rainfall. Minor flooding will continue to affect riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub. As well as areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield and near The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage and Bell Walk, Uckfield. In Isfield flooding will affect locations at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Thursday night, which could cause river levels to rise again. However, we don’t currently think river levels will rise to higher than their peak on Thursday. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Please keep flood protection products installed, if you have them. We have closed our flood gate in Uckfield town centre to reduce flood risk. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.description: Silk Stream and the Deans, Edgware, Dollis, Mutton and Wealdstone Brooks

items.message:
River levels in the Hendon, Wembley, Harrow, Wealdstone, Edgware and Stanmore areas have now fallen following heavy rainfall in the early hours of this morning, Thursday 3rd November 2022. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast this evening, and into tomorrow morning, Friday 4th November but we do not expect any further flooding. 

We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and clearing trash screens where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days. There is currently more heavy rain forecast on Sunday 6th November.

River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall in the early hours of this morning, Thursday 3rd November 2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast this evening, and into tomorrow morning, Friday 4th November but we do not expect any further flooding. 

We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and operating assets where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days. There is currently more heavy rain forecast on Sunday 6th November.

items.message:
This Flood Alert will remain in force overnight tonight, Thursday 3 November 2022 and into tomorrow, Friday 4 November 2022.  The Medway remains high following the heavy rain earlier on Thursday. The river level is now receding at Forest Row and is peaking in the Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst areas.  
There will be further heavy showers overnight tonight and these will keep river levels high in all locations. Any flood impacts should be confined to fields, footpaths and roads. The internal flooding to property is not expected. 

This message will be updated again by 8am on Friday 4 November 2022.

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy and persistent rainfall overnight and during the morning of Thursday. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected today, 03/11/2022 and through until Friday. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into Friday 04/11/2022. River levels have begun to fall at Horley and have stabilised at Kinnersley Manor. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing trash screens across the catchment. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 04/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Trowbridge Paxcroft river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning and afternoon 03/11/22.  We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Heather Shaw Road and West Ashton Road on the Paxcroft Brook and riverside properties at Southwick, Lambrok Close, Berkeley Road, Acacia Crescent and Albion Drive on the Lambrok Stream. River levels have risen overnight   and have reacted  to  the heavy persistent rain   Flood water could be deep and fast flowing, and therefore pose a risk to life.
Further showery  rainfall is forecast over the next  12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until over the next few days and react to  further rainfall..
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Thursday  afternoon 03/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Lee from Hoddesdon to Canning Town

floodArea.county: Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Hackney, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Newham, Tower Hamlets, Waltham Forest

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the Lower River Lee from Hoddesdon to Canning Town as a result of persistent heavy rainfall on Wednesday 2nd and Thursday 3rd November 2022. The risk of flooding to roads and low-lying land is now reducing but river levels remain high. 

Further light rainfall is forecast this evening, Thursday 3rd November 2022 but we do not expect river levels to rise again as a result. We expect river levels to remain high overnight until tomorrow morning, Friday 4th November. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels, and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures. 
 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations.

items.description: Rivers on the Isle of Sheppey
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Our incident response staff are are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from on the Scrapsgate Drain. 
We will continue to monitor the river levels and re-issue this alert if necessary.

River levels in Buxted are still high, but are now slowly falling, following Thursday morning's heavy rain. Thursday afternoon (03/11/2022) should remain largely dry, but flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens throughout Thursday evening, including riverside properties near the White Hart pub in Buxted and around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. There is uncertainty in the forecast but there is a possibility of some heavy showers passing through Sussex on Thursday evening, which could cause river levels to rise again. Riverside properties in Buxted are encouraged to keep their flood protection products installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert will remain in force overnight tonight, Thursday 3 November 2022 and into tomorrow, Friday 4 November 2022.  The River Teise remains high following the heavy rain earlier on Thursday. The river level is now receding sharply at Lamberhurst and is showing signs of peaking in the Horsmonden area.  

There will be further heavy showers overnight tonight and these could keep river levels high into Friday, but not higher than that experienced on Thursday 3 November 2022. Any flood impacts should be confined to fields, footpaths and roads. The internal flooding to property is not expected.

This message will be updated again by 8am on Friday 4 November 2022.

The River Adur is high and rising following Thursday morning's heavy rain. From 15:30 on Thursday (03/11/2022), flooding will affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. Rain is now clearing to the east, leaving a largely dry afternoon. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 on Thursday (03/11/2022) but will be higher than normal until Friday (04/11/2022). Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. There is a chance further rain on Thursday evening could cause river levels to rise again. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 04/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is just peaking at Alverstone. At Sandown, it continues to rise. Last night, a further 16mm of rain was recorded at Knighton. Road, cycle path and footpath flooding is expected. At Alverstone, the river will be close to the top of the river bank, and out of bank flooding is expected at Langbridge. At Sandown, Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will be flooded. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while the river is high. Property flooding is not currently expected. Rain has now cleared the area, and Friday is forecast to be dry. At Alverstone, the river level will begin falling later this morning (04/11/22). At Sandown, the river will not peak until this evening (04/11/22). Further showers are forecast this weekend. If these affect the area, river levels will be high throughout this period. We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to reduce water levels across Brading marshes. Please ensure products used to protect gardens and property are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 16:00 on Friday 04/11/22.

items.description: River Bourne from Hadlow to East Peckham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert will remain in force overnight tonight, Thursday 3 November 2022 and into tomorrow, Friday 4 November 2022.  The River Bourne remains high following the heavy rain earlier on Thursday. The river level is now gradually receding at Hadlow and at Little Mill.  

There will be further heavy showers overnight tonight and these will keep river levels high in all locations. Any flood impacts should be confined to fields, footpaths and roads. The internal flooding to property is not expected.  

This message will be updated again by 8am on Friday 4 November 2022.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Blackwater as a result of persistent heavy rainfall last night. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads, footpaths and farmland is expected this evening today, especially in the Camberley area. 
Tonight, and tomorrow will be relatively dry, with a few light showers, therefore levels should start to fall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/11/22, or if the situation changes.

The River Ouse remains high following Thursday's heavy rain. In the early hours of Friday another 15mm of rain was recorded, and the upper Ouse near Ardingly is rising again. Flood impacts will continue to affect all communities through Friday, including near Ardingly and Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, rural roads and gardens near Freshfield Mill Farm on Sloop Lane, Bridge Cottage at Sheffield Park, Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, and areas of Barcombe Mills, with Anchor Lane and Barcombe Mills Road affected by flood water. River levels should fall Friday afternoon and the river return to a more normal level by Saturday 05/11/2022. However, 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, could cause some further flooding. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 04/11/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall overnight into tomorrow, but further rain is expected at the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Teise and Lesser Teise area from Horsmonden to Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert will remain in force overnight tonight, Thursday 3 November 2022 and into tomorrow, Friday 4 November 2022.  The Teise and the Lesser Teise remain high following the heavy rain earlier on Thursday. The river level is now receding sharply up at Lamberhurst and the peak is reaching Stonebridge and Spitz Bridge around 9pm on Thursday evening.  

The peak in the Yalding area is forecast to occur in the early hours of Friday morning where true Flood Alert conditions may not even be experienced. There will be further heavy showers overnight tonight and these will keep river levels high in all locations. Any flood impacts should be confined to fields, footpaths and roads but showers could also generate localised surface water flooding.  

This message will be updated again by 8am on Friday 4 November 2022.

items.description: Bumpstead Brook through Steeple Bumpstead to New England
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. The forecast is for further unsettled weather over the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Bull River is high in Hellingly, following 50mm of rain recorded at Vines Cross Thursday morning. Flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Minor flood impacts are also likely to affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The Cuckmere River through Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Mill Lane, Hellingly has already started to fall and conditions should improve here. In Alfriston, river levels could keep rising until 04:00 04/11/2022. Showers are possible Thursday evening, which could cause further rises in river levels in Hellingly overnight. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including the locations within this message. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 04/11/2022.

items.description: River Teise in Lamberhurst and Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land in the Lamberhurst and Goudhurst areas.  Further heavy showers are forecast overnight tonight, clearing on Friday morning.

River levels are now falling, having peaked in Lamberhurst early afternoon on Thursday 3 November 2022 but still pose a flood risk to roads, gardens and fields.  

We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are ensuring that rivers are flowing freely and that any structures are working correctly.

items.description: Windle Brook and Hale, Mill and Addlestone Bournes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Windle Brook, Hale Bourne, Mill Bourne, Addlestone Bourne

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

The River Uck is high in Isfield but is now falling, after more than half a month's rain (60mm) was recorded at Buxted during Thursday morning (03/11/22). Flooding will continue to affect properties at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge as well as fields, rural roads and gardens. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Thursday evening, which could cause river levels to rise again. However, we don’t currently think river levels in Isfield will rise higher than their peak seen on Thursday afternoon. It should be mostly dry on Friday which should allow the Uck to fall to nearer normal levels. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Please keep flood protection products installed in Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert will remain in force overnight tonight, Thursday 3 November 2022 and into tomorrow, Friday 4 November 2022. The Rother remains high following the heavy rain earlier on Thursday. The river level is now receding steadily upstream of Etchingham and the peak reached Etchingham around 8pm. The level is high in Robertsbridge but will peak about 10pm Thursday evening. The peaks at Bodiam and Newenden will be in the early hours of Friday morning. 

There will be further heavy showers overnight tonight and these will keep river levels high in all locations. Any additional flood impacts should be confined to fields, footpaths and roads but showers could also generate localised surface water flooding.  

This message will be updated again by 8am on Friday 4 November 2022.

items.description: River Teise and Lesser Teise between Horsmonden and Claygate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land in areas around Goudhurst, Marden and Collier Street. 

River levels are now falling but still pose a risk to roads, gardens and fields. Today, Friday 4 November 2022, will be dry but further rainfall is forecast from Saturday evening, 5 November 2022. 

We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected today, 03/11/2022 and through until Friday. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high throughout today and throughout Friday 04/11/2022. River levels have stabilised at Kinnersley Manor, however they are continuing to steadily rise at Brockham, Dorking, Leatherhead and Cobham. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing trash screens across the catchment. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 04/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land around Etchingham. River levels are now falling but still pose a risk to roads, gardens and fields. Today, Friday 4 November 2022, will be dry but further rainfall is forecast from Saturday evening, 5 November 2022.

We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is high following 46mm of rainfall Thursday. Flooding will continue to affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as there being extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. River levels have now started to slowly fall. Flood impacts should slowly begin to ease. However, showers Thursday evening could cause river levels to rise again Friday morning. We do not think river levels will rise to significantly higher than they have been on Thursday. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 04/11/2022.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely over the next few hours and into tomorrow, Thursday, and into Friday 4th November. The River Wid is rising steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. Further outbreaks of rain are expected today and overnight, clearing the area by tomorrow morning. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9pm tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely over the next few hours and into tomorrow, Thursday, and into Friday 4th November. Spixworth Beck is rising steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth,  Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. Further outbreaks of rain are expected today and overnight, clearing the area by tomorrow morning. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9pm tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The River Medway has risen as a result of heavy rainfall in Kent during Thursday 3 November 2022.  Localised flooding in the vicinity of the river is expected to occur between 4pm on Thursday 3 November 2022, and 10am on Friday 4 November.  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas in Yalding, Wateringbury, Teston, East Farleigh and Maidstone.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners and ensuring our structures are operating correctly.  
  
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely in the early hours of the morning on Friday 4th November, from 4am to 7am. River levels will gradually rise overnight following this evening's tide, and remain high through the early morning tide. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect and the heavy rainfall in the last 24 hours draining through the River Waveney. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely in the early hours of the morning on Friday 4th November from 4am to 7am. River levels will gradually rise overnight following this evening's tide, and remain high through the early morning tide. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect, and the heavy rainfall in the last 24 hours draining through the River Yare. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 4th November.

The Bull River through Hellingly is high and rising. 50mm of rain has been measured at Vines Cross on Thursday. This is a lot in a short period of time, more than we'd normally expect over two weeks. From 18:00 03/11/2022 flooding will affect gardens and properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Nearby fields and rural roads will be affected too. The Cuckmere River through Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Mill Lane, Hellingly has already started to fall and conditions should improve here. There is uncertainty in the weather forecast. Although showers are possible Thursday evening, the Bull River should begin to fall in Hellingly by 20:00 03/11/2022, but not returning to normal until Friday afternoon. If heavy showers occur from 21:00 Thursday 03/11/2022, river levels could yet rise overnight. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 04/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message:
Over the last 24 hours we have had heavy rainfall over the North Devon area causing river levels to rise.  Some areas may receive an additional 30-40 mm of rain in a few hours which could lead to some flooding impacts.

Rivers in this area likely to respond quickly and flooding to low lying land and roads is possible. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

The River Ouse remains very high through Barcombe, following Thursday's heavy rain. River levels are currently falling, but flood impacts will continue to affect a small number of properties in Barcombe Mills and at the Anchor Inn, with Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane likely to be impassable. Flood water will continue to be extensive through fields. In the early hours of Friday another 15mm of rain was recorded, and the upper Ouse near Ardingly is rising again. This will likely slow the fall in water level at Barcombe, possibly causing a slight rise Friday afternoon. A dry day Friday should see the river return to a more normal level by Saturday 05/11/2022. However, 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, could cause some further flooding. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 04/11/2022.

items.description: Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin area

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Caen, Bradiford Water, River Yeo

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message: Flooding is possible tonight Thursday the 3rd of November and through the early hours of Friday morning.  Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall and the river Tamar has risen to the Flood Alert level.  We expect the river to remain high throughout Friday morning, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.  Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. 50mm of rain has been measured at Vines Cross on Thursday. This is a lot in a short period of time, more than we'd normally expect over two weeks. From 01:00 04/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. There is uncertainty in the weather forecast. Although there have been showers Thursday evening, the Cuckmere should begin to fall in Alfriston by 04:00 Friday 04/11/2022, but not returning to normal until the weekend. Due to showers overnight, river levels could rise on Friday. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 04/11/2022.

River levels are rising steadily on the Middle Dorset Stour due to rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne between 07:30 AM and 03:00 PM on 04/11/2022.
No further rainfall is forecast.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 02:30 PM on 04/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 8am today, Friday 4 November 2022 through the morning as a result of recent rainfall overnight.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. No further rainfall is expected today. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. Please avoid using footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 6pm, or as the situation changes.
